key_title: Key to the species of Lomandra

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the families in the Asparagales-Liliales complex

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Xanthorrhoeaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Conn, B.J. (1994). Xanthorrhoeaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers surrounded by deeply fringed bracts such that inflorescence appears woolly
Flowers surrounded by entire or only slightly split bracts; inflorescence never appearing woolly
Leaves terete; basal sheath absent; inflorescence composed of 1–7 spike-like spherical clusters
Leaves flat; basal sheath gradually tapering distally, intact or torn; inflorescence composed of 1 to several spike-like cylindric clusters
Perianth of male flowers fused into a tube in the basal half; perianth of female flowers free for most of their length
Perianth parts of male and female flowers free to base
Leaf-sheath with margin ± abruptly tapered at top (approaching blade at an angle of c.45°), highly shredded, often brownish; leaf apex rounded-truncate or broadly acute; eastern Victoria

Leaf-sheath with margin narrowing gradually at top (meeting with blade at an angle of c. 30°), not much shredded or much-shredded and whitish; leaf apex truncate to long-acute; chiefly western Victoria

Leaves mostly 15–40 cm long, straight, acute or long-rounded at apex, not dilated below, often waxy-glaucous; sheaths highly shredded; male inflorescences branched (in all but depauperate plants); mostly north-western Victoria

Leaves mostly 5–17 cm long, often curved, obtuse or truncate at apex (often slightly dilated just below apex), green to somewhat bluish but hardly waxy; sheaths usually not copiously shredded; male inflorescence unbranched (very rarely with 1 or 2 weak branches); mostly south and west from about Seymour
Male and female flowers grouped in whorls or many-flowered clusters
Male and female flowers arranged singly or in 2- or 3-flowered clusters
Leaf apex entire
Leaf apex with 2 or 3 points
Leaves up to 1.5 mm wide; bracts not or sometimes only slightly exceeding the flower clusters; far east only
Leaves more than 2 mm wide; bracts usually exceeding flower clusters; widespread
Male flower with pedicel at least 1 mm long
Male flower sessile
Leaf apex with a distinct sinus between 2 sharp lateral points
Leaf apex subacute or broadly acute to obtuse, entire, or with 1–3 minute points that are often soon eroded
Perianth segments of male flowers similar
Outer perianth segments of male flowers shorter and thinner-textured than inner
Leaves often gently twisted longitudinally, hemispherical, biconvex or concavo-convex to folded (in cross section), 1–2 mm wide
Leaves flat, not twisted, often with margin incurved or slightly concavo-convex, mostly 3–5 mm wide
Leaves terete or semiterete; far East Gippsland only
Leaves flat, channelled, folded or inrolled
Leaf apex distinctly toothed
Leaf apex entire or with 1–3 minute points
